However, in the one round where we both pick R, I would earn 45$, so my expected payoff per round would be (1*45 - 74*42)/75 = (-298/75 + 45/75) = 5.87$ per round.

2. If they always pick B: I will choose B in this case as well. In each round, I would get 12$. However, there is no round where we both pick B and I get 45$, so my expected payoff per round would be 12$ per round.

Since the expected payoff for choosing B when they always pick R (5.87$) is greater than the expected payoff for choosing B when they always pick B (12$), it suggests that my opponent might not always pick R, which means there could be an advantage in occasionally picking R to take advantage of their potential deviations from strictly picking R.
